results.title: A Company of Men
results.creator_credit: Basic Films, Leon Clore and Fred Moore
results.brief_description: Focuses attention on the more delicate question of the prejudices and resistance which may be encountered at all levels when Work Study is introduced into industry. The story is based on the day-to-day record of a six-months period in an engineering firm in the Midlands, and is presented as a realistic account of the difficulties experienced and overcome, in an effort to bring fundamental problems into open discussion.

results.title: A Communications primer
results.brief_description: This visually beautiful film was a first in a lot of ways: the Eameses’ first film scored by Elmer Bernstein, their first to deal with specific intellectual content, and the film that introduced their work to IBM. The elegant and clear statement remains essential viewing for the Media Age. The film deals with the ways in which human beings obtain their essential knowledge of the outside world. It has not always been recognised that communications consist of something more than the transmission of facts or symbols, and a mere facility for handling certain devices. What is required is an understanding of the human attributes and processes which control the passage of information from one person to another. The film will help discourage a limited view of communications. There are a number of philosophical implications, and some good illustrative samples on the concept of noise in a communication system, and provocative photographic symbolism about the power of words to add or detract to human knowledge. Music by Elmer Bernstein, sound by Barry Eddy.

results.title: A Colour box
results.brief_description: The purely abstract “A Colour Box” was Len Lye’s first experiment with painting in colour directly onto celluloid. After its initial release in 1935, John Grierson acquired the film for the United Kingdom General Post Office, and it was re-released in 1937 as an advertisement, with the addition of a “cheaper parcel post” message. Note: this film has been restored by the National Film and Television Archive (UK) from Lye’s original material using the Eastmancolor process.

results.title: A Collection of carols
results.creator_credit: New Official Films and William Forest Crouch
results.brief_description: Come all ye faithful; “The First Noel”; “It Came upon a midnight clear”; “Joy to the world”; “Hark! The Herald angels’ sing”; “Silent night”. A gang of morose adolescent boys besiege the doors of a church, overhead, a radioactive space baby illuminates the night sky. Drawings detail the unsavoury habits of certain rural communities as shepherds obscenely fondle their ward and throughout a vigorous stentorian choir sings hymns of praise.

results.title: A Class of your own
results.creator_credit: Stewart Films, John R.F. Stewart and Richard Need
results.brief_description: Primarily designed for the instruction of the services, this film puts forward principles that are equally applicable to teaching in the civilian field. The instructor must plan his lessons in advance, whether in the classroom or at the workbench. The lesson should have a proper introduction, be developed logically, and flow naturally and interestingly to its concluding summary. The value of class activity, teaching aids, planned questions and proper note-taking are all dealt with in this film. The film falls into two parts: classroom instruction and practical instruction.

results.title: A Class for Tommy
results.brief_description: Story of the establishment of an experimental training class for mentally handicapped children. Purposes of the class are to determine if such children will progress more satisfactorily in elementary school if given special training at an early age; whether certain undesirable attitudes and reactions may be prevented by early enrolment in such a program; and to establish desirable behaviour patterns at an early age in order to allow the child a more nearly normal happy life.

results.title: A Class Divided
results.creator_credit: WGBH Educational Foundation and William Peters
results.brief_description: Jane Elliott divided her classroom into blue-eyed and brown-eyed children to teach them the degrading effects of discrimination. “A Class Divided” shows the result of her teaching on the adults who took her class as children in the 1960’s. Her teaching method was so successful that it has been used as a basis for training workshops on racism within the US prison system, and is used by business companies to expose racist attitudes amongst employees and employers. Elliott herself says that the “necessity for this exercise is a crime. But I think this exercise ought to be taught by every teacher.”

results.title: A Civilised malady
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and John Sexton
results.brief_description: An investigation of the causes, incidence, social impact and cures of one of modern civilisations most insidious diseases, high blood pressure. Common salt is suspected of being the prime cause of this disease. In Australia one in six adults suffer from hypertension, but only half of those affected know that they have it.

results.title: A City speaks
results.creator_credit: Films of Fact, Manchester City Corporation and Paul Rotha
results.brief_description: While dealing specifically with Manchester, England, this film is also intended to give a general picture of local government in England. A summary of Manchester’s growth through the centuries is given, stressing the rapid growth during the industrial revolution. Manchester’s past achievements and future plans are shown in some detail. Sequences showing Manchester at play are cut to the music of Wagner’s “Ride of the Valkyries”. The concluding sequences show citizens going about their work, while the commentary stresses that the city is its people.

results.title: A City reborn
results.creator_credit: Victor Gruen Associates and Peter Reinshagen
results.brief_description: Illustrates good city planning, showing how Fresno, California, has revitalised its city centre by a plan implemented from 1964, diverting traffic from the city core, turning the main street into a long pedestrian mall. Contrasts the success of the plan with the inner city congestion and suburban disorganisation of many cities.
